conclusion: To solve for the temperature of the gas in state A, we need to use the ideal gas law and the fact that the product \( pV \) is proportional to the temperature \( T \) when the number of moles \( n \) and the gas constant \( R \) are constant.
The ideal gas law is given by: \[ pV = nRT \]. For a fixed amount of gas (\( n \) is constant), we can write: \[ \frac{p_1 V_1}{T_1} = \frac{p_2 V_2}{T_2} \]
State C: \( p_C = 5 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \) m³, \( T_C = 300 \) K
State A: \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_A = 5 \times 10^{-3} \) m³

premise: Using the relationship between states A and C: \[ \frac{p_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{p_C V_C}{T_C} \]
conclusion: Substitute the known values into the equation: \[ \frac{(3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}) (5 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{T_A} = \frac{(5 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}) (2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{300 \text{ K}} \]

premise: Simplify the right-hand side: \[ \frac{15 \times 10^2 \text{ Pa} \cdot \text{m}^3}{T_A} = \frac{10 \times 10^2 \text{ Pa} \cdot \text{m}^3}{300 \text{ K}} \]
Cross-multiply to solve for \( T_A \): \[ 1500 \times 300 = 1000 \times T_A \]
